awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: A Quantitative Framework for the Flow of Metals in Nearby Galaxies
awd_abstract_narration:
Chemical elements, such as oxygen and nitrogen, are forged in the interior of stars. When stars end their lives as supernova explosions, many of these elements are expelled and mix into the local environment within a galaxy. These expelled elements are the seeds for future generations of stars and planets. If there are enough supernova explosions, or if the galaxy is small, some of the elements will leave the galaxy entirely and end up in intergalactic space. Therefore, measuring the types of elements in galaxies, and finding where the elements are located, give important clues about the history of galaxies in the Universe.  These investigators will perform optical and radio wavelength observations of 36 nearby galaxies to study how galaxies produce, distribute, and expel elements. Their research results will help us understand how galaxies change over time and will be used as input to galaxy formation models. 

Fundamentally, the observed gas-phase metallicities in nearby galaxies should correspond to the production and release of stellar nucleosynthesis products and, thus, provide a robust trace of galaxy formation and life cycle. Global scaling relations, such as the mass-metallicity relation, show gas-phase metallicities increase steeply with galaxy mass. The investigators seek to build an over-arching, quantitative framework of the production, transport, distribution, and retention of metals in low-mass galaxies.  Specifically, they will determine the full chemical enrichment histories of a statistical sample of low-mass galaxies in the nearby universe from a comprehensive set of spectroscopic and imaging data.

The investigators, both women astronomers, will work to develop a diverse, globally competitive STEM workforce by working with undergraduate and graduate students on this research project.  Additionally, their research highlights will be broadcasted on the public "StarDate" Radio program to an audience of 750,000. The co-investigator will continue to lead nationwide efforts to reduce interference at radio wavelengths.  The efforts to reduce radio interference are critical for enabling radio astronomy research.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit:

Galaxy evolution is driven by the process of turning gas into stars and the subsequent return of chemically enriched material and energy. This material and energy can be deposited locally, increasing the turbulence and chemical content of the surrounding gas; if the star formation is vigorous enough, material can also be expelled from a galaxy and deposited into the surrounding medium. The cumulative impact of this process is thought to be mass dependent. Low-mass galaxies have lower star formation rates and efficiencies and produce correspondingly less chemical enriched material and energy than more massive spirals, but low-mass galaxies are also predicted to lose a greater percentage of that material via outflows because they have less gravity.

This research program directly measured the impact of star formation process on galaxies over the critical mass range where star formation energetics is predicted to dramatically shape galaxy properties. Specifically, the study found the timescale over which the energy of star formation correlates with the turbulence in the local gas is ~100 Myr in low-mass systems, much longer than previously thought. In addition, using multi-wavelength observations, a sample of low-mass galaxies with recent star formation all showed evidence of galactic-scale winds and/or fountains of material being expelled. Despite the existence of the winds, the observations suggest that the majority of material expelled is rather modest, does not escape from the host galaxy's gravity, and may eventually be recycled back to the system. The overall amount of material ejected relative to the star formation activity driving the process was found to be much lower than predicted, and in tension with values predicted from galaxy simulations. Together, these results created a detailed framework for understanding how feedback from star formation changes the local and global properties of low-mass galaxies. 

Broader Impact:

This award has supported the work of two graduate students, two post-doctorate scholars, and three undergraduate students, including two women, two transgender people, and two people from traditionally under-represented populations in the physical sciences. The students who have graduated have pursued careers in STEM fields and one post-doc has moved into a prestigious fellowship position in astrophysics. The results from this program were broadly disseminated to the public via a segment on StarDate Radio, which broad-casts to an audience of 750,000. The proposed scientific program also provided the foundation for active advocacy for an interference-free radio spectrum for radio astronomy applications.
